title: Part A
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

Each criterion is achieved independently.
descriptions:
The response does not accomplish the task set by part A of the question.

Part A: Describe an aspect of Bantu or Swahili society that is not included in the source.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • International trade was an important part of the economy along the Swahili Coast.

  • The Swahili Coast linked Africa’s interior to Arab, Persian, Indian, and Chinese trading communities.

  • The Swahili language is one of hundreds of related Bantu languages that are spoken throughout West, Central, and Southern Africa.

The response accomplishes the task set by part A of the question.

Part A: Describe an aspect of Bantu or Swahili society that is not included in the source.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • International trade was an important part of the economy along the Swahili Coast.

  • The Swahili Coast linked Africa’s interior to Arab, Persian, Indian, and Chinese trading communities.

  • The Swahili language is one of hundreds of related Bantu languages that are spoken throughout West, Central, and Southern Africa.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

Each criterion is achieved independently.
descriptions:
The response does not accomplish the task set by part B of the question.

Part B: Describe one way societies such as the ones described in the source challenge misconceptions about early Africa.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • East Africa’s coastal city-states were linked to Arab, Persian, Indian, and Chinese trading communities.

  • Early African societies had diversified economies with various economic enterprises.

  • The Swahili people had constructed ships that enabled them to travel along the coast and to Asia.

  • The migration of Bantu speakers from West Africa to regions such as the Swahili Coast gave rise to city-states, unified in part by a common language.

The response accomplishes the task set by part B of the question.

Part B: Describe one way societies such as the ones described in the source challenge misconceptions about early Africa.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • East Africa’s coastal city-states were linked to Arab, Persian, Indian, and Chinese trading communities.

  • Early African societies had diversified economies with various economic enterprises.

  • The Swahili people had constructed ships that enabled them to travel along the coast and to Asia.

  • The migration of Bantu speakers from West Africa to regions such as the Swahili Coast gave rise to city-states, unified in part by a common language.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

Each criterion is achieved independently.
descriptions:
The response does not accomplish the task set by part C of the question.

Part C: Formulate a claim about how political factors contributed to the fall of the city-states on the Swahili Coast.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • The wealth and strength of the Swahili Coast trading states attracted the attention of the Portuguese whose invasion contributed to the weakening of the city-states.

  • The Portuguese invaded major city-states and established settlements in the sixteenth century to control Indian Ocean trade; this change threatened the independence of the city-states on the Swahili Coast.

  • The Swahili Coast trading states were not connected to a central political authority, which made them vulnerable to outside forces.

The response accomplishes the task set by part C of the question.
